comment_text: I just got mine yesterday and came from glowforge so was super nervous about how user friendly it would be. Everything worked great out of the box- I followed Cam’s setup instructions. But now running lightburn on my daughter’s pc it is working great. Much more powerful /fast/capable than my glowforge plus and wow for the price. If you follow the unboxing and setup videos that are on YouTube, read the manual thoroughly, then it doesn’t take long to understand it and get running. TBD if I can get my Mac to recognize it. Also 7mm hold down pins was my first cut and that appears to be the sweet spot

video_title: $4000 cheaper than Glowforge AND better?  OMTech Polar Review
comment_text:
Glowforge is a compete pos. Prior to buying my 50w Omtech, I rented a Glowforge from a friend, and it was 100% unusable because you HAVE TO scan the bed with the camera prior to every burn. So, if you think you’re going to design something and pound a bunch of them out, 1 after the other, you’re going to be seriously disappointed. It makes no difference that every piece is on exactly the same material and there is no need to scan every time. You HAVE TO. Their software is crap and replacement parts are more trouble than their worth.

I had a Lightburn camera on my Omtech. I took it out and threw it away. I can’t imagine what could possibly be the use for something so wildly inaccurate, and that’s after having spent far too much time mastering the calibration procedure. I’d disagree with the statement that Omtech support is great. It’s not. I had an issue with a loose X axis belt. I spent several days going back and forth with them and their suggestions for what to do had nothing - literally zero - to do with the problem, which was a loose belt. I figured it out on my own. Aside from that, I’ve been VERY happy with the machine and I’m coming up on a year of using it for production manufacturing.

I find literally the same designs and drawings all over. Researching petroglyphs in Southwest USA turned up two designs created by uncredited authors being sold on mugs, tshirts, woodcraft, metal craft, etc. by at least 10 different sellers... as their own work. When a creator does publish build files, code, etc., you can subsequently find that design being sold online as some douche's original work.

Some people are actual creators. Everyone else seems to be ripoff artists.

video_title: 6 Mistakes Not to Make When Building a Farmhouse Table
comment_text:
1:25 and even if you don't have a table saw you can just plane it by hand. No need to buy all kinds of powertools.
1:55 dowels are optional. They can help against slippage while gluing, maybe even make the joints marginally stronger, but you don't actually need them.
2:20 this is actually nonsense. If you alternate the directions you're going to get a wavy surface. You're averaging out the warping, but not stopping the warping. If you keep them all in one direction and make sure it wants to bow in an upward arch, if you then fasten the middle securely the entire rail the top rests on will stop it from warping altogether (that is, unless there's so much force the fastening doesn't hold, but you shouldn't get such moisture extremes indoors).
40:20 you did the breadboard wrong. In the board itself you can just drill holes, but the part it slides over can only have a normal drill hole in the middle (to keep the breadboard centered). The other holes need to be elongated slots rather than just holes, so the pins going through them have room to move sideways (but not length wise obviously). Just a few millimeters, but what you've done now is basically the same as screwing the board on. This creates stress. Also, there's no need to glue it in the middle. You can, but you should glue less wide than you did. Just a bit around the centre pin.
 4:20 yup, you need to practice planing. Especially sharpening your plane. Make it sharp, slightly round the corners, use a shallow setting, work methodically, and you won't have marks. Also, you need to check whether the sole of your plane is flat. 

Good on you for keeping practicing and wanting to learn!

video_title: The Most Powerful Laser Diode? NEJE Master 2S Plus A40640 Laser
comment_text: There are a couple ways to get a stable focus, either eyeballing it or drawing lines on an inclined plane (too much to go in to here--search Youtube).  But once you find the height, measure it with calipers.  Then make a block that height--in my case, I 3D printed a simple rectangular block, was able to get within 0.05mm of the desired height, I think.  Then, if you want to etch, place your block on top of the etching surface, and let the laser module rest on the block while tightening.  If you want to burn, set your block on the empty honeycomb (or whatever sacrificial surface), and let the module rest on the block while tightening--remove the block and insert your material to burn.  This puts the focal length at the bottom of the material.  Note, this only works for up to a few millimeters of material.

comment_text: You are having problems with aluminium because you are not using the correct type of end mill. If the mill is chocking up use an end mill with more flutes or a higher rotation speed. Also you need mills with cutting geometry specifically for soft metals like aluminium and brass on low powered machines like this. If you had tried this with brass it would have probably given even worse results because brass is so soft it tends to grab the cutter so definitely needs correct end mills with the correct geometry. Also a shorter end mill will help and repositioning the spindle higher up in the mount will produce less stresses in the z axis and gantry assemblies.

video_title: What Can a $500 CNC Do? Genmitsu 3020 Pro Max
comment_text:
I bought this 3020 in Nov 2021 strictly for aluminum cutting. I’ve been using a competitors machine for over a decade and it works great. I was disappointed with this machine and had several issues. It will cut aluminum but not not very well. The 1/8” bit must be all the way in the shaft. (And to prevent milling the table it’s best to lower the Z axis to the lowest point and raise the spindle in the holder so the bit can’t reach the table.) But the spindle is just not rigid enough to handle the cutting, the length of the shaft allows slight flexing. And the spindle doesn’t have enough speed or torque. I found that even slowly cutting a 1” hole in 2mm aluminum with 9 passes was nail biting. It did cut the hole but was a struggle. The finished hole was a few thousands under size because the spindle rigidity was causing it to flex inward. And just drilling a 1/8” hole w the milling bit would sputter when reaching the bottom, and wallowed the hole almost every time. So to fix both issues I hack sawed the spindle holder (another problem-only a 55mm spindle fits), and mounted a $70 rotozip (600W 30K RPM) with metal strapping. Now it mills, drills, and cuts much better. Note that after less than 10 hours the 300W spindle stopped working.

The other issue I had was that most all of the USB software I tried wouldn’t run a few commands of my existing gcode. Also, it was essential that I could stop and start the gcode from any gcode line, and couldn’t do it! So, to get around those problems I abandoned the USB controller and bought a parallel stepper driver and use LinuxCNC (or Mach2).

Overall it’s a nice little machine but wouldn’t recommend for aluminum unless your into mods.
